Multi-Armed Bandit Based Client Scheduling for Federated Learning

Wenchao Xia, Tony Q. S. Quek, , Kun Guo, Wanli Wen,
Howard H. Yang, , and Hongbo Zhu W. Xia, T. Q. S. Quek, K. Guo, W. Wen, and H. H. Yang are with the Information Systems Technology and Design Pillar, Singapore University of Technology and Design, Singapore 487372, (e-mails: wenchao_xia@sutd.edu.sg, tonyquek@sutd.edu.sg, kun_guo@sutd.edu.sg, wanli_wen@sutd.edu.sg, howard_yang@sutd.edu.sg).H. Zhu is with the Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Wireless Communications, and also with the Engineering Research Center of Health Service System Based on Ubiquitous Wireless Networks, Ministry of Education, Nanjing University of Posts and Telecommunications, Nanjing 210003, China, (e-mail: zhuhb@njupt.edu.cn).
Abstract

By exploiting the computing power and local data of distributed clients, federated learning (FL) features ubiquitous properties such as reduction of communication overhead and preserving data privacy. In each communication round of FL, the clients update local models based on their own data and upload their local updates via wireless channels. However, latency caused by hundreds to thousands of communication rounds remains a bottleneck in FL. To minimize the training latency, this work provides a multi-armed bandit-based framework for online client scheduling (CS) in FL without knowing wireless channel state information and statistical characteristics of clients. Firstly, we propose a CS algorithm based on the upper confidence bound policy (CS-UCB) for ideal scenarios where local datasets of clients are independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.) and balanced. An upper bound of the expected performance regret of the proposed CS-UCB algorithm is provided, which indicates that the regret grows logarithmically over communication rounds. Then, to address non-ideal scenarios with non-i.i.d. and unbalanced properties of local datasets and varying availability of clients, we further propose a CS algorithm based on the UCB policy and virtual queue technique (CS-UCB-Q). An upper bound is also derived, which shows that the expected performance regret of the proposed CS-UCB-Q algorithm can have a sub-linear growth over communication rounds under certain conditions. Besides, the convergence performance of FL training is also analyzed. Finally, simulation results validate the efficiency of the proposed algorithms.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, client scheduling, client selection, multi-armed bandit (MAB)

I Introduction

The unprecedented amount of data and the increasing number of mobile devices, e.g., smart phones, tablets, and Internet of Things (IoT) devices, in wireless communication networks, together with the recent breakthroughs in machine learning (ML), are revolutionizing our way of life. While traditional ML frameworks rely on the availability of a large amount of data in a centralized computing entity, this is not always feasible in IoT applications due to: (a) the reluctance of sharing private data from the end users, (b) the growing security concerns, and (c) the large communication overhead required to transmit raw data to centralized ML processors. In response, federated learning (FL) [1] was recently proposed to leverage massively distributed computing power, e.g., on IoT devices or smart phones, to collaboratively train a shared ML model without direct access to raw data. These devices, which are referred to as clients, train an ML model on their local datasets, respectively, and then upload their local model parameters (e.g., model weights or gradients) to a remote server for model aggregation. Thus, the massive amount of distributed and privacy-sensitive data on the clients can be well exploited without leak of privacy.

Unfortunately, latency incurred by wireless transmission and local computation on clients remains a bottleneck in FL, since hundreds to thousands of communication rounds are required to reach a desired model accuracy, especially when the number of participating clients in the training process of FL is large [2]. Specifically, the large propagation latency caused by dynamic wireless environment and the large computation delay due to limited computing power of clients will degrade model performance, if with a limited training time budget. The approaches to reducing the training latency in FL proposed in existing works can be roughly divided into three main categories: update compression, over-the-air computation, and communication reduction. Belonging to the first category, gradient quantization [3] and gradient sparsification [4, 5] can be used to improve the communication efficiency. Besides, two ways to reduce the uplink communication costs: structured updates and sketched updates of model parameters were proposed in [6]. Recognizing the superposition property of wireless multiple-access channels, computation-over-the-air approaches which harness interference instead of suppressing interference are shown to be able to accelerate global model aggregation, such as broadband analog aggregation adopted in [7, 8, 9]. The last category has also been investigated in some works. For example, the adaptive communication strategies with dynamic local updates and with dynamic model aggregation were proposed by [10] and [11], respectively.

In addition to the aforementioned methods, client scheduling (CS) is also an important direction to reduce training latency in FL, especially in the scenarios with massive number of clients but limited wireless channels. Different scheduling criterions lead to different performance. For example, in [12] only a portion of clients with fast response were chosen for aggregation and the stragglers with slow response were temporarily dropped in a certain communication round, in order to avoid a long wait for the stragglers. [13, 7] maximized the number of selected clients in each communication round. [14] proposed a scheduling policy by jointly accounting for the staleness of the received parameters and the instantaneous channel qualities. Another scheduling criterion is the update significance such as model variance [11] and gradient variance [15]. Besides, the work in [16, 17] considered a joint problem of wireless resource allocation and CS. Note that these works performed CS based on the assumption that some prior information is available, such as wireless channel state information (CSI) and computing resource usage of clients. However, it is not easy to have access to such information when the number of clients is greatly large. Secondly, most of these works, except for [18, 19], only investigated the transmission time consumption of uploading local updates and distributing global model parameters, but did not take into account the computation time consumption of local training on clients. In addition, due to the potential “deep fade” of wireless channels or the exhausted computing power, some clients may lose their connectivity and be unavailable temporarily. Thus, the availability of clients during FL training is also a practical challenge, but was not considered in these existing works. Motivated by these facts, a new CS policy in FL training is proposed in this paper to deal with these practical challenges.

In this work, given the number of communication rounds required to achieve a certain level of test accuracy [20, 21], we aim to minimize the total wall-clock time consumption including transmission time and local computation time. We consider a system where an access point (AP) equipped with a central processor serves a large amount of clients. However, only a limited number of wireless channels are available, i.e., the number of wireless channels is much smaller than that of clients. Thus, scheduling the appropriate clients to access to the wireless channels for parameter updating during different communication rounds is of necessity. We study the CS problem in FL in two scenarios: ideal and non-ideal scenarios. In the ideal scenario, the clients are always available and the dataset of each client is balanced and independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.). In the non-ideal scenario, the clients are not always available during the FL training process and the datasets of different clients are unbalanced and non-i.i.d. Due to the lack of prior knowledge of training time of the clients, we need to learn the related statistical information while performing CS, so as to help make better decisions in the future. Thanks to the development of reinforcement learning technique, we reformulate the CS problem as a multi-armed bandit (MAB) program, which is a powerful tool for scheduling and resource allocation problems [22, 23, 24]. To our best knowledge, this work is the first attempt to apply the MAB tool to the CS problem in FL.

The contributions of this work are summarized as follows:

  • •

    We formulate a CS problem which aims to minimize the time consumption of the whole FL training including transmission time and local computation time in both ideal and non-ideal scenarios. Then we provide an MAB-based framework to learn to schedule clients online in FL training without knowing wireless CSI and dynamics of computing resource usage of clients.

  • •

    For the ideal scenario, we propose a CS algorithm based on upper bound confidence (UCB) policy [25], namely CS-UCB algorithm, which strikes a balance between the exploitation of actions that performed well in the past and the exploration of actions that might return higher rewards in the future. An upper bound on regret is provided and shows the expected performance regret grows in the logarithmic way over communication rounds.

  • •

    For the non-ideal scenario with non-i.i.d. and unbalanced properties of local datasets and dynamic availability of clients, we introduce the fairness constraint to ensure each client can participate in a certain proportion of the communication rounds during the training process. We further propose a CS algorithm based on UCB policy and virtual queue technique, namely CS-UCB-Q algorithm. An upper bound on regret is also derived and shows that the expected performance regret of the proposed CS-UCB-Q algorithm can have a sub-linear growth over communication rounds under certain conditions.

  • •

    The convergence performance in both the ideal and non-ideal scenarios is analyzed. It is found that increasing the number of the participating clients in each round can improve the convergence rate in the ideal scenario, but the convergence performance has a weak dependence on the number of the participating clients in each round in the non-ideal scenario.

  • •

    Simulation results validate the efficiency of the proposed CS-UCB and CS-UCB-Q algorithms. Besides, A tradeoff between the performance regret and the speed of convergence to a point where the fairness constraint is satisfied is revealed.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section II introduces the system model and formulates the CS problems in both the ideal and non-ideal scenarios. Sections III and IV propose the CS-UCB and CS-UCB-Q algorithms for the ideal and non-ideal scenarios, respectively, and an upper bound on regret is derived for each of the proposed algorithms. In addition, the convergence performance is also analyzed. Numerical results are presented in Section V. Finally, conclusion is drawn in Section VI.

II System Model and Problem Formulation

We consider a wireless network which is composed of a single-antenna AP and massive single-antenna clients (e.g., smart phones, sensors, and cameras). The set of clients is denoted as 𝒦𝒦{\mathcal{K}} with the cardinality |𝒦|=K𝒦𝐾|{\mathcal{K}}|=K. Each client k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in{\mathcal{K}} has a local dataset 𝒲ksubscript𝒲𝑘{\mathcal{W}}_{k} consisting of sk=|𝒲k|subscript𝑠𝑘subscript𝒲𝑘s_{k}=|{\mathcal{W}}_{k}| sample points, based on which local training is performed. The FL training aims to minimize the weighted global loss function [26, 27], which is given as

min𝐱⁡G​(𝐱)=∑k∈𝒦ϖk​Gk​(𝐱),subscript𝐱𝐺𝐱subscript𝑘𝒦subscriptitalic-ϖ𝑘subscript𝐺𝑘𝐱\min_{{\bf x}}G({\bf x})=\sum_{k\in{\mathcal{K}}}\varpi_{k}G_{k}({\bf x}), (1)

where ϖk>0subscriptitalic-ϖ𝑘0\varpi_{k}>0 is the weight of client k𝑘k with ∑k∈𝒦ϖk=1subscript𝑘𝒦subscriptitalic-ϖ𝑘1\sum_{k\in{\mathcal{K}}}\varpi_{k}=1 and Gk​(𝐱)subscript𝐺𝑘𝐱G_{k}({\bf x}) is the local empirical loss of client k𝑘k, which is defined as

Gk​(𝐱)=1sk​∑s′=1skg​(𝐱;𝐰k​s′),subscript𝐺𝑘𝐱1subscript𝑠𝑘subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑘superscript𝑠′1𝑔𝐱subscript𝐰𝑘superscript𝑠′G_{k}({\bf x})=\frac{1}{s_{k}}\sum^{s_{k}}_{s^{\prime}=1}g({\bf x};{\bf w}_{ks^{\prime}}), (2)

where 𝐰k​s′subscript𝐰𝑘superscript𝑠′{\bf w}_{ks^{\prime}} is the s′superscript𝑠′s^{\prime}-th sample point in 𝒲ksubscript𝒲𝑘{\mathcal{W}}_{k} and g​(𝐱;𝐰)𝑔𝐱𝐰g({\bf x};{\bf w}) is a loss function of a parameter vector 𝐱𝐱{\bf x} associated with the sample point 𝐰𝐰{\bf w}.

We assume a fixed amount of spectrum is available and equally divided into N𝑁N orthogonal radio access channels. A wireless channel is allocated to at most one client in each round such that there is no inter-client interference. Due to the scarce of the spectrum resource, the number of available channels is much smaller than that of the candidate clients, i.e., N<K𝑁𝐾N<K. The training procedure of FL is an iterative process consisting of a number of communication rounds. In each round t𝑡t, the AP chooses a subset 𝒮​(t)⊆𝒦𝒮𝑡𝒦{\mathcal{S}}(t)\subseteq{\mathcal{K}} of the clients and then distributes the weight vector 𝐱​(t)𝐱𝑡{\bf x}(t) of the global model to the selected clients. After receiving the global model weights, each of the selected clients individually updates the global model by computing the gradients of their local loss functions based on their own private data and then uploads the updated gradients to the AP for model aggregation, i.e.,

𝐱​(t+1)=𝐱​(t)−γ​𝐯​(t),𝐱𝑡1𝐱𝑡𝛾𝐯𝑡{\bf x}(t+1)={\bf x}(t)-\gamma{\bf v}(t), (3)

where 𝐯​(t)=∑k∈𝒮​(t)ϖk∑k′∈𝒮​(t)ϖk′​∇Gk​(𝐱​(t))𝐯𝑡subscript𝑘𝒮𝑡subscriptitalic-ϖ𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑘′𝒮𝑡subscriptitalic-ϖsuperscript𝑘′∇subscript𝐺𝑘𝐱𝑡{\bf v}(t)=\sum_{k\in{\mathcal{S}}(t)}\frac{\varpi_{k}}{\sum_{k^{\prime}\in{\mathcal{S}}(t)}\varpi_{k^{\prime}}}\nabla G_{k}({\bf x}(t)).

II-A Training Latency

Since the AP has abundant computational resource compared to the clients, the latency incurred by global model aggregation is negligible. According to the above analysis, the time cost of each round t𝑡t of client k𝑘k depends on three main components: distribution time, local update time, and upload time, denoted by τkD​(t)subscriptsuperscript𝜏D𝑘𝑡\tau^{\textrm{D}}_{k}(t), τkLU​(t)subscriptsuperscript𝜏LU𝑘𝑡\tau^{\textrm{LU}}_{k}(t), and τkU​(t)subscriptsuperscript𝜏U𝑘𝑡\tau^{\textrm{U}}_{k}(t), respectively. Then, the total time consumed by client k𝑘k in round t𝑡t is given as

τk​(t)=min⁡{τkD​(t)+τkU​(t)+τkLU​(t),τmax},subscript𝜏𝑘𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝜏D𝑘𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝜏U𝑘𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝜏LU𝑘𝑡subscript𝜏\tau_{k}(t)=\min\{\tau^{\textrm{D}}_{k}(t)+\tau^{\textrm{U}}_{k}(t)+\tau^{\textrm{LU}}_{k}(t),\tau_{\max}\}, (4)

where τmaxsubscript𝜏\tau_{\max} represents the maximal interval of each communication round, which is used to avoid an endless wait caused by possible stragglers. The distribution time τkD​(t)subscriptsuperscript𝜏D𝑘𝑡\tau^{\textrm{D}}_{k}(t) and upload time τkU​(t)subscriptsuperscript𝜏U𝑘𝑡\tau^{\textrm{U}}_{k}(t) of client k𝑘k in round t𝑡t relies on the size of the model parameters and the wireless channel between the AP and client k𝑘k. It is worth noting that the available computing resource on each client varies over time, because a client can execute multiple processing tasks at the same time. For example, a smart phone is used to play games, while performing the local training. To capture the dynamics of local computing power of the clients in FL training and for simplicity, we assume the amount of available computing power on each client k𝑘k in round t𝑡t for the local training, denoted by ϕk​(t)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘𝑡\phi_{k}(t) in sample points per second, is i.i.d. over time according to a certain distribution and its expectation is also unknown a priori. Because of the heterogeneity of available computing power, the resulting local update time τkLU​(t)subscriptsuperscript𝜏LU𝑘𝑡\tau^{\textrm{LU}}_{k}(t) is also different among the clients.

Fortunately, instead of obtaining the values of the three main components separately, the AP in our work observes τk​(t)subscript𝜏𝑘𝑡\tau_{k}(t) directly, which significantly reduces difficulties and overhead.

II-B Availability Constraint

During the FL process, some clients can be unavailable temporarily due to, for example, the poor channel conditions or the exhausted computing power. We define a binary variable ak​(t)subscript𝑎𝑘𝑡a_{k}(t) and if client k𝑘k is available in round t𝑡t, then ak​(t)=1subscript𝑎𝑘𝑡1a_{k}(t)=1; otherwise ak​(t)=0subscript𝑎𝑘𝑡0a_{k}(t)=0. We further define 𝒜​(t)≜{k∈𝒦|ak​(t)=1}∈𝒫​(𝒦)≜𝒜𝑡conditional-set𝑘𝒦subscript𝑎𝑘𝑡1𝒫𝒦{\mathcal{A}}(t)\triangleq\{k\in\mathcal{K}|a_{k}(t)=1\}\in{\mathcal{P}}({\mathcal{K}}) as the set of the available clients in round t𝑡t where 𝒫​(𝒦)𝒫𝒦{\mathcal{P}}({\mathcal{K}}) is the power set of 𝒦𝒦{\mathcal{K}}. For simplicity, it is assumed that the set of the available clients is i.i.d.111For the cases where the set of the available clients is non-i.i.d. over time, we can introduce a Markov process to analyze the upper bound on performance regret [28, 29]. over time and the corresponding distribution of the available clients, P^𝒜​(e)=P^​(𝒜​(t)=e),e∈𝒫​(𝒦)formulae-sequencesubscript^𝑃𝒜𝑒^𝑃𝒜𝑡𝑒𝑒𝒫𝒦\hat{P}_{{\mathcal{A}}}(e)=\hat{P}(\mathcal{A}(t)=e),e\in{\mathcal{P}}({\mathcal{K}}), is unknown in advance. However, 𝒜​(t)𝒜𝑡\mathcal{A}(t) is revealed to the AP at the beginning of each round t𝑡t. Note that in the considered network the number of the clients is much larger than that of the available channels, thus the AP has to choose a subset 𝒮​(t)𝒮𝑡{\mathcal{S}}(t) from the available clients, i.e.,

𝒮​(t)≜{𝒮​(t)⊆𝒜​(t):|𝒮​(t)|≤min⁡{N,|𝒜​(t)|}}∈𝒬​(𝒜​(t)),≜𝒮𝑡conditional-set𝒮𝑡𝒜𝑡𝒮𝑡𝑁𝒜𝑡𝒬𝒜𝑡{\mathcal{S}}(t)\triangleq\{{\mathcal{S}}(t)\subseteq{\mathcal{A}}(t):|{\mathcal{S}}(t)|\leq\min\{N,|{\mathcal{A}}(t)|\}\}\in{\mathcal{Q}}({\mathcal{A}}(t)), (5)

where |𝒮​(t)|𝒮𝑡|\mathcal{S}(t)| represents the cardinality of 𝒮​(t)𝒮𝑡\mathcal{S}(t) and 𝒬​(𝒜​(t))𝒬𝒜𝑡{\mathcal{Q}}({\mathcal{A}}(t)) is the power set of 𝒜​(t)𝒜𝑡{\mathcal{A}}(t).

II-C Fairness Constraint

Besides the availability constraint, the non-i.i.d. and unbalanced properties of local datasets of the clients should be addressed. More specifically, the local dataset of any particular client cannot represent the distribution of the whole, and the sizes of the local datasets of different clients are different, because different clients have various activity characteristics. An effective solution to the considered issue is Federated Averaging approach [1] in which a subset of the clients are enrolled in the FL process in each round to cooperatively train a shared model. However, the importance of the local datasets of different clients is different. Generally speaking, the local dataset which has a larger size and whose distribution is more similar to the global distribution plays a more important role, and the corresponding clients should participate in more communication rounds. Thus, fairness constraint is introduced to “tell” each client that how many communication rounds they should participate in. The fairness constraint not only can avoid the occurrence of abandoning the slow but important clients due to the pursuit of low delay, but also can make the important clients be involved in more rounds by setting a large fairness factor. A binary variable bk​(t)subscript𝑏𝑘𝑡b_{k}(t) is defined as an indicator with bk​(t)=1subscript𝑏𝑘𝑡1b_{k}(t)=1 indicating that client k𝑘k is selected in round t𝑡t, and bk​(t)=0subscript𝑏𝑘𝑡0b_{k}(t)=0 otherwise. Then, the fairness constraint is formulated as [30]

limT→∞inf1T​∑t=1T𝔼​[bk​(t)]≥ck,∀k∈𝒦,formulae-sequencesubscript→𝑇infimum1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑏𝑘𝑡subscript𝑐𝑘for-all𝑘𝒦\lim\limits_{T\rightarrow\infty}\inf\frac{1}{T}\sum\nolimits_{t=1}^{T}{\mathbb{E}}[b_{k}(t)]\geq c_{k},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (6)

where 𝔼​[⋅]𝔼delimited-[]⋅{\mathbb{E}}[\cdot] is the expectation operator and ck∈[0,1)subscript𝑐𝑘01c_{k}\in[0,1) is the minimum fraction of communication rounds required to choose client k𝑘k. Since the distribution of the local dataset is usually unknown, we use the size of the local dataset as a metric to roughly describe the importance and set the fairness constraint. Here, we provide a heuristic example of the setting of the fairness constraint. We first find client k^=arg​mink∈𝒦⁡sk^𝑘subscriptargmin𝑘𝒦subscript𝑠𝑘\hat{k}=\operatornamewithlimits{arg\,min}_{k\in{\mathcal{K}}}{s_{k}} and set ck^=cminsubscript𝑐^𝑘subscript𝑐c_{\hat{k}}=c_{\min}, where φ​N​sk^∑k∈𝒦sk≤cmin≤N​sk^∑k∈𝒦sk𝜑𝑁subscript𝑠^𝑘subscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝑠𝑘subscript𝑐𝑁subscript𝑠^𝑘subscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝑠𝑘\varphi\frac{Ns_{\hat{k}}}{\sum_{k\in{\mathcal{K}}}s_{k}}\leq c_{\min}\leq\frac{Ns_{\hat{k}}}{\sum_{k\in{\mathcal{K}}}s_{k}} and 0≤φ<10𝜑10\leq\varphi<1. The fairness constraint values of the other clients are set as ck=sksk^​cmin,k≠k^formulae-sequencesubscript𝑐𝑘subscript𝑠𝑘subscript𝑠^𝑘subscript𝑐𝑘^𝑘c_{k}=\frac{s_{k}}{s_{\hat{k}}}c_{\min},k\neq\hat{k}.

These constraint values, {ck}k=1Ksubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑐𝑘𝐾𝑘1\{c_{k}\}^{K}_{k=1}, are incorporated into a vector 𝐜=[c1,c2,…,cK]†𝐜superscriptsubscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2…subscript𝑐𝐾†\mathbf{c}=[c_{1},c_{2},\ldots,c_{K}]^{\dagger}, where [⋅]†superscriptdelimited-[]⋅†[\cdot]^{\dagger} denotes the transpose operator. If there exists a policy that can find a time sequence {𝒮​(t),t≥1}𝒮𝑡𝑡1\{{\mathcal{S}}(t),t\geq 1\} to satisfy the constraint in (6), then the constraint vector 𝐜𝐜\mathbf{c} is said to be feasible, otherwise infeasible. For example, any 𝐜𝐜\mathbf{c} satisfying ∑k∈𝒦ck>Nsubscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝑐𝑘𝑁\sum_{k\in{\mathcal{K}}}c_{k}>N is infeasible. Furthermore, we denote by 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}} the maximal feasibility region which includes all such feasible 𝐜𝐜\mathbf{c}’s.

II-D Problem Formulation

During each communication round, the AP cannot perform model aggregation until all the selected clients finish data uploading, thus the time consumption of each round t𝑡t is determined by the slowest client, i.e.,

τ^​(t,𝒮​(t))=maxk∈𝒮​(t)⁡τk​(t).^𝜏𝑡𝒮𝑡subscript𝑘𝒮𝑡subscript𝜏𝑘𝑡\hat{\tau}(t,{\mathcal{S}}(t))=\max_{k\in{\mathcal{S}}(t)}\tau_{k}(t). (7)

In the following, for simplicity, τ^​(t,𝒮​(t))^𝜏𝑡𝒮𝑡\hat{\tau}(t,{\mathcal{S}}(t)) is written as τ^​(𝒮​(t))^𝜏𝒮𝑡\hat{\tau}({\mathcal{S}}(t)) without ambiguity. This work considers both ideal and non-ideal scenarios. In the ideal scenario, all the clients are available anytime and the local datasets of the clients are i.i.d. and balanced, thus it is unnecessary to take the availability constraint and the fairness constraint into account. In addition, the convergence rate improves substantially as the number of the participating clients in each round increases [31]. Thus, constraint (5) can be simplified as

𝒮​(t)≜{𝒮​(t):|𝒮​(t)|=N}∈𝒫​(𝒦).≜𝒮𝑡conditional-set𝒮𝑡𝒮𝑡𝑁𝒫𝒦{\mathcal{S}}(t)\triangleq\{{\mathcal{S}}(t):|{\mathcal{S}}(t)|=N\}\in{\mathcal{P}}({\mathcal{K}}). (8)

We aim to minimize the time cost of the FL training process, by finding a decision sequence {𝒮​(t),t≥1}𝒮𝑡𝑡1\{{\mathcal{S}}(t),t\geq 1\}, i.e.,

min{𝒮​(t),t≥1}∑t=1Tτ¯​(𝒮​(t))​η​(t),s.t.​η​(t)∈{0,1}and(​8​),\begin{split}\mathop{\min}_{\{{\mathcal{S}}(t),t\geq 1\}}\ \sum_{t=1}^{T}\bar{\tau}({\mathcal{S}}(t))\eta(t),\ \ \text{s.t.}\ \eta(t)\in\{0,1\}\ \ \text{and}\ \ \eqref{availability constraint2},\end{split} (9)

where T𝑇T is a large constant, τ¯​(𝒮​(t))=τ^​(𝒮​(t))τmax∈(0,1]¯𝜏𝒮𝑡^𝜏𝒮𝑡subscript𝜏01\bar{\tau}({\mathcal{S}}(t))=\frac{\hat{\tau}({\mathcal{S}}(t))}{\tau_{\max}}\in(0,1] is the normalized delay, and η​(t)=1𝜂𝑡1\eta(t)=1 is an indicator, which equals 1 if the FL process does not converge and 0 otherwise [32].

However, in the non-ideal scenario, the clients can be unavailable during the learning process and the local datasets of different clients are non-i.i.d. and unbalanced, thus the fairness constraint and the availability constraint should be addressed. Note that under the non-i.i.d. scenario, the convergence rate has a weak dependence on the number |𝒮​(t)|𝒮𝑡|{\mathcal{S}}(t)| of the participating clients in each round [27]. As mentioned in Section II, the number of the clients is much larger than that of the available channels in the considered network. Thus, for simplicity, it is reasonable to make full use of available channels and select as many clients as possible in each round, i.e.,

𝒮​(t)≜{𝒮​(t)⊆𝒜​(t):|𝒮​(t)|=min⁡{N,|𝒜​(t)|}}∈𝒬​(𝒜​(t)).≜𝒮𝑡conditional-set𝒮𝑡𝒜𝑡𝒮𝑡𝑁𝒜𝑡𝒬𝒜𝑡{\mathcal{S}}(t)\triangleq\{{\mathcal{S}}(t)\subseteq{\mathcal{A}}(t):|{\mathcal{S}}(t)|=\min\{N,|{\mathcal{A}}(t)|\}\}\in{\mathcal{Q}}({\mathcal{A}}(t)). (10)

Then, the underlaying problem, with the availability and fairness constraints, is formulated as

min{𝒮​(t),t≥1}∑t=1Tτ¯​(𝒮​(t))​η​(t),s.t.​η​(t)∈{0,1},(​6​),and​(​10​).\begin{split}\mathop{\min}_{\{{\mathcal{S}}(t),t\geq 1\}}\ \sum_{t=1}^{T}\bar{\tau}({\mathcal{S}}(t))\eta(t),\ \ \text{s.t.}\ \eta(t)\in\{0,1\},\eqref{fairness constraint},\ \text{and}\ \eqref{availability constraint3}.\end{split} (11)

Solving the scheduling problems (9) and (11) is not easy because of the lack of prior information. We do not know either the dynamics of computing power of the clients or wireless CSI between the AP and clients, so that we cannot make the optimal decisions. In order to address this issue, we must learn some important information, i.e., the statistical information about time consumption of each client, from the feedback from the previous decisions. Besides, the fairness constraint and the availability constraint increase the difficulty in solving problem (11). In the following, we will first handle problem (9), and then we take a further step to deal with problem (11).

III Scheduling in Ideal Scenario

In this section, we first give a short introduction to MAB problems, then reformulate problem (9) into an MAB problem and propose an algorithm to find the decision sequence {𝒮​(t)}t=1Tsubscriptsuperscript𝒮𝑡𝑇𝑡1\{{\mathcal{S}}(t)\}^{T}_{t=1} in the ideal scenario. Finally, we provide some theoretical analysis on the performance of the proposed algorithm.

III-A MAB Problems

An MAB problem is one of sequential decision problems, where a player should make a decision, in each time slot, about which arms of the bandits are pulled [33]. We refer to arm pulls as an action and a reward (payoff) is observed when an action is taken. The aim of an MAB problem is to make sequential decisions to maximize the total reward obtained in a sequential of actions. Due to the limited information available, the player has to strike a balance between the exploitation of actions that performed well in the past and the exploration of actions that might return higher rewards in the future [34].

III-B Problem Reformulation

The scheduling problem (9) can be modelled as an MAB problem, where the AP and the clients can be regarded as the player and the arms, respectively. The chosen subset of the arms 𝒮​(t)𝒮𝑡{\mathcal{S}}(t) is referred to as a super arm and its corresponding normalized reward is r​(𝒮​(t))=−τ¯​(𝒮​(t))+1∈[0,1)𝑟𝒮𝑡¯𝜏𝒮𝑡101r({\mathcal{S}}(t))=-\bar{\tau}({\mathcal{S}}(t))+1\in[0,1). Accordingly, the objective of problem (9) can be interpreted as finding a time sequence of actions, according to a particular policy, to maximize the cumulative reward, i.e.,

max{𝒮​(t),t≥1}​∑t=1Tr​(𝒮​(t))​η​(t).subscript𝒮𝑡𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇𝑟𝒮𝑡𝜂𝑡\max_{\{{\mathcal{S}}(t),t\geq 1\}}\sum_{t=1}^{T}r({\mathcal{S}}(t))\eta(t). (12)

For the scheduling problem (12), we evaluate the policies of action selection with respect to regret [33], which is defined as the difference between the expected reward of the optimal actions and that obtained by the given policy. Note that minimizing the regret is equivalent to maximizing the total reward. We denote by μk=𝔼​[rk​(t)]subscript𝜇𝑘𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑟𝑘𝑡\mu_{k}={\mathbb{E}}\left[r_{k}(t)\right] the expectation of the normalized reward rk​(t)=−τk​(t)τm​a​x+1subscript𝑟𝑘𝑡subscript𝜏𝑘𝑡subscript𝜏𝑚𝑎𝑥1r_{k}(t)=-\frac{\tau_{k}(t)}{\tau_{max}}+1 of arm k𝑘k, and the optimal super arm is

𝒮∗=arg​max𝒮⊆𝒦,|𝒮|=N⁡{mink∈𝒮⁡μk}.superscript𝒮∗subscriptargmaxformulae-sequence𝒮𝒦𝒮𝑁subscript𝑘𝒮subscript𝜇𝑘{\mathcal{S}}^{\ast}=\operatornamewithlimits{arg\,max}_{{\mathcal{S}}\subseteq{\mathcal{K}},|{\mathcal{S}}|=N}\{\min_{k\in{\mathcal{S}}}\mu_{k}\}. (13)

Assume that η​(T)=1𝜂𝑇1\eta(T)=1 and η​(T+1)=0𝜂𝑇10\eta(T+1)=0, meaning that the FL training converges at the end of round T𝑇T. Then, the cumulative regret of a given policy π1subscript𝜋1\pi_{1} is

Σπ1=T​μ​(𝒮∗)−𝔼​[∑t=1Tr​(𝒮​(t))],superscriptΣsubscript𝜋1𝑇𝜇superscript𝒮∗𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇𝑟𝒮𝑡\Sigma^{\pi_{1}}=T\mu({\mathcal{S}}^{\ast})-{\mathbb{E}}\left[\sum_{t=1}^{T}r\Big{(}{\mathcal{S}}(t)\Big{)}\right], (14)

where μ​(𝒮)=mink∈𝒮⁡μk𝜇𝒮subscript𝑘𝒮subscript𝜇𝑘\mu({\mathcal{S}})=\min_{k\in{\mathcal{S}}}\mu_{k} is the expectation of the reward of the super arm 𝒮𝒮{\mathcal{S}}. Then, problem (9) can be reformulated as

min{𝒮​(t),t≥1}Σπ1,s.t.​(​8​).\begin{split}\mathop{\min}_{\{{\mathcal{S}}(t),t\geq 1\}}\ \Sigma^{\pi_{1}},\ \ \text{s.t.}\ \eqref{availability constraint2}.\end{split} (15)

III-C Proposed Algorithm

As shown in Algorithm 1, the proposed algorithm for problem (15) is based on UCB policy [25, 35], namely CS-UCB algorithm. The key idea behind this algorithm is that we observe the feedbacks for each arm, rather than for each super arm (or each action) as a whole. The same arm can be observed in different actions and we collect and exploit information about the reward of one certain arm from the operations of different actions, in order to make better decisions in the future.

We define two vectors 𝐲​(t)∈ℝK×1𝐲𝑡superscriptℝ𝐾1\mathbf{y}(t)\in\mathbb{R}^{K\times 1} and 𝐳​(t)∈ℝK×1𝐳𝑡superscriptℝ𝐾1\mathbf{z}(t)\in\mathbb{R}^{K\times 1}. yk​(t)subscript𝑦𝑘𝑡y_{k}(t) is the k𝑘k-th element of 𝐲​(t)𝐲𝑡\mathbf{y}(t) and represents the sample mean of the observed reward values of arm k𝑘k up to the current round t𝑡t, which is updated by the following rule:

yk​(t)={yk​(t−1)​zk​(t−1)+rk​(t−1)zk​(t−1)+1,if​k∈𝒮​(t),yk​(t−1),else,subscript𝑦𝑘𝑡casessubscript𝑦𝑘𝑡1subscript𝑧𝑘𝑡1subscript𝑟𝑘𝑡1subscript𝑧𝑘𝑡11if𝑘𝒮𝑡subscript𝑦𝑘𝑡1elsey_{k}(t)=\begin{cases}\frac{y_{k}(t-1)z_{k}(t-1)+r_{k}(t-1)}{z_{k}(t-1)+1},\ &\text{if}\ k\in{\mathcal{S}}(t),\\ y_{k}(t-1),\ &\text{else},\end{cases} (16)

where zk​(t)subscript𝑧𝑘𝑡z_{k}(t) is the k𝑘k-th element of 𝐳​(t)𝐳𝑡\mathbf{z}(t) and denotes the number of times that arm k𝑘k is played by the end of round t𝑡t, which is updated as follows:

zk​(t)={zk​(t−1)+1,if​k∈𝒮​(t),zk​(t−1),else.subscript𝑧𝑘𝑡casessubscript𝑧𝑘𝑡11if𝑘𝒮𝑡subscript𝑧𝑘𝑡1elsez_{k}(t)=\begin{cases}z_{k}(t-1)+1,\ &\text{if}\ k\in{\mathcal{S}}(t),\\ z_{k}(t-1),\ &\text{else}.\end{cases} (17)

Note that both 𝐳𝐳\mathbf{z} and 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y} are initialized to 𝟎0\bm{0} when t=0𝑡0t=0, i.e., 𝐳​(0)=𝐲​(0)=0𝐳0𝐲00\mathbf{z}(0)=\mathbf{y}(0)=0.

In Algorithm 1, we use κ=⌈KN⌉𝜅𝐾𝑁\kappa=\lceil\frac{K}{N}\rceil rounds for initialization to make sure each arm is played at least one time. After initialization, Algorithm 1 enters the main loop and selects a super arm in each round t𝑡t according to

𝒮​(t)=arg​max𝒮∈𝒫​(𝒦),|𝒮|=N∑k∈𝒮(yk​(t−1)+(N+1)​ln⁡tzk​(t−1)),𝒮𝑡subscriptargmaxformulae-sequence𝒮𝒫𝒦𝒮𝑁subscript𝑘𝒮subscript𝑦𝑘𝑡1𝑁1𝑡subscript𝑧𝑘𝑡1{\mathcal{S}}(t)=\mathop{\operatornamewithlimits{arg\,max}}_{{\mathcal{S}}\in{\mathcal{P}}({\mathcal{K}}),|{\mathcal{S}}|=N}\sum_{k\in{\mathcal{S}}}\left(y_{k}(t-1)+\sqrt{\frac{(N+1)\ln t}{z_{k}(t-1)}}\right), (18)

where yk​(t−1)subscript𝑦𝑘𝑡1y_{k}(t-1) and (N+1)​ln⁡t/zk​(t−1)𝑁1𝑡subscript𝑧𝑘𝑡1\sqrt{(N+1)\ln t/z_{k}(t-1)} correspond to exploitation and exploration, respectively. Note that the size of 𝒫​(𝒦)𝒫𝒦{\mathcal{P}}({\mathcal{K}}) in exponential in K𝐾K. Thus, the complexity of the combinatorial problem (18) can be very high and some efficient algorithms should be developed [36]. Thanks to the special structure of linear reward, where the rewards of different arms in (18) are independent on each other, we can find the best super arm 𝒮​(t)𝒮𝑡{\mathcal{S}}(t) by iteratively choosing the best individual arms. More specifically, we can sort the clients in descending order of the rewards and choose the top N𝑁N clients. In what follows, we provide the analysis of the upper bound of regret Σπ1superscriptΣsubscript𝜋1\Sigma^{\pi_{1}} which is logarithmic in T𝑇T and polynomial in K𝐾K.

III-D Upper Bound on Regret

Theorem 1.

The expected regret achieved by the proposed CS-UCB algorithm presented in Algorithm 1 is upper bounded by

Σπ1<Δmax​[KN+1+4​N2​(N+1)​K​ln⁡T(Δmin)2+K+π23​N​K],superscriptΣsubscript𝜋1subscriptΔdelimited-[]𝐾𝑁14superscript𝑁2𝑁1𝐾𝑇superscriptsubscriptΔ2𝐾superscript𝜋23𝑁𝐾\Sigma^{\pi_{1}}<\Delta_{\max}\left[\frac{K}{N}+1+\frac{4N^{2}(N+1)K\ln T}{(\Delta_{\min})^{2}}+K+\frac{\pi^{2}}{3}NK\right], (19)

where Δmax=maxr​(𝒮)≤r​(𝒮∗)⁡Δ𝒮subscriptΔsubscript𝑟𝒮𝑟superscript𝒮∗subscriptΔ𝒮\Delta_{\max}=\max_{r({\mathcal{S}})\leq r({\mathcal{S}}^{\ast})}\Delta_{{\mathcal{S}}}, Δ𝒮=∑k∈𝒮∗μk−∑k∈𝒮μksubscriptΔ𝒮subscript𝑘superscript𝒮∗subscript𝜇𝑘subscript𝑘𝒮subscript𝜇𝑘\Delta_{{\mathcal{S}}}=\sum_{k\in{\mathcal{S}}^{\ast}}\mu_{k}-\sum_{k\in{\mathcal{S}}}\mu_{k}, and Δmin=minr​(𝒮)≤r​(𝒮∗)⁡Δ𝒮subscriptΔsubscript𝑟𝒮𝑟superscript𝒮∗subscriptΔ𝒮\Delta_{\min}=\min_{r({\mathcal{S}})\leq r({\mathcal{S}}^{\ast})}\Delta_{{\mathcal{S}}}.

Proof:

The sketch of the proof is provided in Appendix A and refer to [35] for more details. ∎

According to Theorem 1, the regret grows as 𝒪​(N3​K​ln⁡T)𝒪superscript𝑁3𝐾𝑇\mathcal{O}(N^{3}K\ln T), i.e., polynomially in the number of wireless channels, linearly in the number of clients, and strictly logarithmically in the number of communication rounds. Given that N𝑁N and K𝐾K are fixed, the gap between the optimal solution and the proposed CS-UCB algorithm becomes smaller in the logarithmic way in T𝑇T.

III-E Convergence Analysis

In the ideal scenario, it is assumed that the local datasets of the clients are balanced and the sample points in each 𝒲ksubscript𝒲𝑘{\mathcal{W}}_{k} are sampled i.i.d. from the same source distribution 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W}, i.e., 𝒲k⊆𝒲,∀k∈𝒦formulae-sequencesubscript𝒲𝑘𝒲for-all𝑘𝒦\mathcal{W}_{k}\subseteq\mathcal{W},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. Thus, the weights ϖksubscriptitalic-ϖ𝑘\varpi_{k}’s are set with the same value, i.e., ϖk=1N,∀k∈𝒦formulae-sequencesubscriptitalic-ϖ𝑘1𝑁for-all𝑘𝒦\varpi_{k}=\frac{1}{N},\forall k\in{\mathcal{K}}. In the following, we first highlight the necessary assumptions and then provide the convergence guarantee.

Assumption 1.

(Unbiased evaluation) Given gs^​(𝐱)=∑s′=1s^g​(𝐱;𝐰s′)subscript𝑔^𝑠𝐱superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑠′1^𝑠𝑔𝐱subscript𝐰superscript𝑠′g_{\hat{s}}({\bf x})=\sum_{s^{\prime}=1}^{\hat{s}}g({\bf x};{\bf w}_{s^{\prime}}), where 𝐰s′subscript𝐰superscript𝑠′{\bf w}_{s^{\prime}}’s are i.i.d sampled from 𝒲𝒲{\mathcal{W}}. gs^subscript𝑔^𝑠g_{\hat{s}} is an unbiased estimator of the global loss function G𝐺G, i.e., 𝔼​[gs^​(𝐱)]=G​(𝐱)𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑔^𝑠𝐱𝐺𝐱{\mathbb{E}}[g_{\hat{s}}({\bf x})]=G({\bf x}).

Assumption 2.

(L-smoothness) G​(𝐱)𝐺𝐱G({\bf x}) is L-smooth, i.e., G​(𝐱′)−G​(𝐱)≤∇G†​(𝐱)​(𝐱′−𝐱)+L2​‖𝐱′−𝐱‖22𝐺superscript𝐱′𝐺𝐱∇superscript𝐺†𝐱superscript𝐱′𝐱𝐿2superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscript𝐱′𝐱22G({\bf x}^{\prime})-G({\bf x})\leq\nabla G^{\dagger}({\bf x})({\bf x}^{\prime}-{\bf x})+\frac{L}{2}||{\bf x}^{\prime}-{\bf x}||_{2}^{2}.

Assumption 4.

It is observed from Theorem 2 that as N𝑁N increases, the gap between G​(𝐱​(T))𝐺𝐱𝑇G({\bf x}(T)) and G​(𝐱∗)𝐺superscript𝐱∗G({\bf x}^{\ast}) becomes smaller, suggesting a better convergence performance.

IV Scheduling in Non-ideal Scenario

In this section, problem (11) is investigated which takes both the availability constraint and the fairness constraint into account. Similar to problem (9), we first reformulate (11) as an MAB problem, but Algorithm 1 cannot be applied to problem (11) directly because of the fairness constraint. The availability constraint can be addressed by checking the availability of clients before choosing an action in Algorithm 1 [25], but satisfying the fairness constraint has to resort to other approaches. Motivated by [38, 30], we apply the virtual queue technique to handle the fairness constraint.

IV-A Problem Reformulation

To address the uncertainty of the set of the available clients, we consider the special class of stationary and randomized policies named 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}-only policies, which observe 𝒜​(t)𝒜𝑡{\mathcal{A}}(t) in each round t𝑡t and independently select a super arm 𝒮​(t)∈𝒬​(𝒜​(t))𝒮𝑡𝒬𝒜𝑡\mathcal{S}(t)\in\mathcal{Q}({\mathcal{A}}(t)) as a pure (possibly randomized) function of the observed 𝒜​(t)𝒜𝑡\mathcal{A}(t) only [38]. We define a vector of probability distributions 𝐪=[q𝒮(e),∀𝒮∈𝒬(e),∀e∈𝒫(𝒦)]\mathbf{q}=[q_{{\mathcal{S}}}(e),\forall{\mathcal{S}}\in{\mathcal{Q}}(e),\forall e\in{\mathcal{P}}({\mathcal{K}})] to describe an 𝒜𝒜{\mathcal{A}}-only policy π𝜋\pi where q𝒮​(e)subscript𝑞𝒮𝑒q_{{\mathcal{S}}}(e) is the probability that the super arm 𝒮𝒮{\mathcal{S}} is chosen when the set e∈𝒫​(𝒦)𝑒𝒫𝒦e\in{\mathcal{P}}({\mathcal{K}}) of the available arms is observed. Note that ∑𝒮∈𝒬​(e)q𝒮​(e)=1,∀e∈𝒫​(𝒦)formulae-sequencesubscript𝒮𝒬𝑒subscript𝑞𝒮𝑒1for-all𝑒𝒫𝒦\sum_{{\mathcal{S}}\in{\mathcal{Q}}(e)}{q_{{\mathcal{S}}}(e)}=1,\forall e\in\mathcal{P}({\mathcal{K}}). Then, based on the 𝒜𝒜{\mathcal{A}}-only policy π𝜋\pi, the mean of bk​(t)subscript𝑏𝑘𝑡b_{k}(t) for all t𝑡t’s is given as

𝔼​[bkπ​(t)]=∑e∈𝒫​(𝒦)P^𝒜​(e)​∑𝒮∈𝒬​(e):k∈𝒮q𝒮​(e),𝔼delimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝑏𝜋𝑘𝑡subscript𝑒𝒫𝒦subscript^𝑃𝒜𝑒subscript:𝒮𝒬𝑒𝑘𝒮subscript𝑞𝒮𝑒{\mathbb{E}}[b^{\pi}_{k}(t)]=\sum_{e\in{\mathcal{P}}({\mathcal{K}})}\hat{P}_{{\mathcal{A}}}(e)\sum_{{\mathcal{S}}\in{\mathcal{Q}}(e):k\in{\mathcal{S}}}q_{{\mathcal{S}}}(e), (21)

and the fairness constraint (6) is equivalent to 𝔼​[bkπ​(t)]≥ck𝔼delimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝑏𝜋𝑘𝑡subscript𝑐𝑘{\mathbb{E}}[b^{\pi}_{k}(t)]\geq c_{k}. Furthermore, the following lemma is obtained.

Lemma 1 ([38]).

There always exists an 𝒜𝒜{\mathcal{A}}-policy π𝜋\pi that can meet the fairness constraint specified by a vector 𝐜𝐜\mathbf{c}, i.e.,

𝔼​[bkπ​(t)]≥ck,∀k∈𝒦,formulae-sequence𝔼delimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝑏𝜋𝑘𝑡subscript𝑐𝑘for-all𝑘𝒦{\mathbb{E}}[b^{\pi}_{k}(t)]\geq c_{k},\forall k\in{\mathcal{K}}, (22)

if 𝐜𝐜\mathbf{c} is strictly inside the maximal feasibility region 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}}.

Proof:

The proof is very similar to the proof of Theorem 4.5 in [38] and hence is omitted here. ∎

Assume that the expectation μksubscript𝜇𝑘\mu_{k} of the normalized reward of each arm k𝑘k is known in advance, the normalized reward μ​(𝒮)𝜇𝒮\mu({\mathcal{S}}) of the super arm 𝒮𝒮{\mathcal{S}} is a constant. Based on Lemma 1, we can reformulate problem (11) as a linear program:

max𝐪∑e∈𝒫​(𝒦)P^𝒜​(e)​∑𝒮∈𝒬​(e)q𝒮​(e)​μ​(𝒮)s.t.∑e∈𝒫​(𝒦)P^𝒜​(e)​∑𝒮∈𝒬​(e):k∈𝒮q𝒮​(e)≥ck,∀k∈𝒦,∑𝒮∈𝒬​(e)q𝒮​(e)=1,∀e∈𝒫​(𝒦),q𝒮​(e)∈[0,1],∀𝒮∈𝒬​(e),∀e∈𝒫​(𝒦),formulae-sequencesubscript𝐪subscript𝑒𝒫𝒦subscript^𝑃𝒜𝑒subscript𝒮𝒬𝑒subscript𝑞𝒮𝑒𝜇𝒮s.t.subscript𝑒𝒫𝒦subscript^𝑃𝒜𝑒subscript:𝒮𝒬𝑒𝑘𝒮subscript𝑞𝒮𝑒subscript𝑐𝑘formulae-sequencefor-all𝑘𝒦formulae-sequencesubscript𝒮𝒬𝑒subscript𝑞𝒮𝑒1formulae-sequencefor-all𝑒𝒫𝒦formulae-sequencesubscript𝑞𝒮𝑒01formulae-sequencefor-all𝒮𝒬𝑒for-all𝑒𝒫𝒦\begin{split}\mathop{\max}_{{\bf q}}\ &\sum_{e\in{\mathcal{P}}({\mathcal{K}})}\hat{P}_{{\mathcal{A}}}(e)\sum_{{\mathcal{S}}\in{\mathcal{Q}}(e)}q_{{\mathcal{S}}}(e)\mu({\mathcal{S}})\\ \text{s.t.}\ &\sum_{e\in{\mathcal{P}}({\mathcal{K}})}\hat{P}_{{\mathcal{A}}}(e)\sum_{{\mathcal{S}}\in{\mathcal{Q}}(e):k\in{\mathcal{S}}}q_{{\mathcal{S}}}(e)\geq c_{k},\forall k\in{\mathcal{K}},\\ &\sum_{{\mathcal{S}}\in{\mathcal{Q}}(e)}{q_{{\mathcal{S}}}(e)}=1,\forall e\in{\mathcal{P}}({\mathcal{K}}),\\ &q_{{\mathcal{S}}}(e)\in[0,1],\forall{\mathcal{S}}\in{\mathcal{Q}}(e),\forall e\in{\mathcal{P}}({\mathcal{K}}),\end{split} (23)

whose optimal solution is easy to find due to its linearity. However, the linear program is based on the assumption that the normalized expectation of each arm’s reward is known in advance, which is usually impractical. Thus, to achieve the maximal reward, the player (i.e., the AP) needs to estimate the mean rewards of the arms and exploit such knowledge to find out a super arm that seems to yield the highest reward, but also keep exploring further the other arms to identify with better precision which super arm is actually the best. Such a learning process is a typical exploration-exploitation tradeoff and inevitably leads to the reward loss, i.e., the regret [33]. Similar to problem (15), we use the regret as the metric to evaluate the performance. Given an optimal 𝒜𝒜{\mathcal{A}}-policy π∗superscript𝜋∗\pi^{\ast}, we define r∗superscript𝑟∗r^{\ast} as the maximal reward of problem (23) with known reward expectation μk,k∈𝒦subscript𝜇𝑘𝑘𝒦\mu_{k},k\in{\mathcal{K}}, which is given as

r∗=∑e∈𝒫​(𝒦)P^𝒜​(e)​∑𝒮∈𝒬​(e)q𝒮∗​(e)​μ​(𝒮),superscript𝑟∗subscript𝑒𝒫𝒦subscript^𝑃𝒜𝑒subscript𝒮𝒬𝑒subscriptsuperscript𝑞∗𝒮𝑒𝜇𝒮r^{\ast}=\sum_{e\in{\mathcal{P}}({\mathcal{K}})}\hat{P}_{{\mathcal{A}}}(e)\sum_{{\mathcal{S}}\in{\mathcal{Q}}(e)}q^{\ast}_{{\mathcal{S}}}(e)\mu({\mathcal{S}}), (24)

where q𝒮∗subscriptsuperscript𝑞∗𝒮q^{\ast}_{{\mathcal{S}}} is the associated probability distribution of policy π∗superscript𝜋∗\pi^{\ast}. Assume that the FL training converges at the end of round T𝑇T, i.e., η​(T)=1𝜂𝑇1\eta(T)=1 and η​(T+1)=0𝜂𝑇10\eta(T+1)=0. Then, problem (11) is equivalent to the minimization of the cumulative regret under a policy π2subscript𝜋2\pi_{2} by choosing a super arm 𝒮​(t)𝒮𝑡{\mathcal{S}}(t) in each round t𝑡t, i.e.,

min{𝒮​(t),t≥1}⁡Σπ2=T​r∗−𝔼​[∑t=1Tr​(𝒮​(t))],s.t.​(​6​)​and​(​10​).\begin{split}\min_{\{{\mathcal{S}}(t),t\geq 1\}}\ \Sigma^{\pi_{2}}=Tr^{\ast}-{\mathbb{E}}\bigg{[}\sum_{t=1}^{T}r({\mathcal{S}}(t))\bigg{]},\ \ \text{s.t.}\ \eqref{fairness constraint}\ \text{and}\ \eqref{availability constraint3}.\end{split} (25)

IV-B Proposed Algorithm

As shown in Algorithm 2, the proposed algorithm for problem (25) is based on policy UCB [25] and virtual queue technique [38], which is referred to as CS-UCB-Q algorithm. Recall that yk​(t)subscript𝑦𝑘𝑡y_{k}(t) is the the empirical average of the observed reward of arm k𝑘k up to the current round t𝑡t and zk​(t)=∑t′=1tbk​(t′)subscript𝑧𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑡′1𝑡subscript𝑏𝑘superscript𝑡′z_{k}(t)=\sum_{t^{\prime}=1}^{t}b_{k}(t^{\prime}) is the number of times that arm k𝑘k has been played up to the current round t𝑡t. Then, we use a truncated UCB estimate to calculate the reward of each arm k𝑘k,

y^k​(t)=min⁡{yk​(t−1)+2​ln⁡tzk​(t−1),1}.subscript^𝑦𝑘𝑡subscript𝑦𝑘𝑡12𝑡subscript𝑧𝑘𝑡11\hat{y}_{k}(t)=\min\{y_{k}(t-1)+\sqrt{\frac{2\ln t}{z_{k}(t-1)}},1\}. (26)

Note that y^k​(t)=1subscript^𝑦𝑘𝑡1\hat{y}_{k}(t)=1, if zk​(t−1)=0subscript𝑧𝑘𝑡10z_{k}(t-1)=0.

To deal with the fairness constraint, we introduce a virtual queue Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} for each arm k𝑘k as follows

Dk​(t)=[Dk​(t−1)+ck−bk​(t−1)]+,subscript𝐷𝑘𝑡superscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐷𝑘𝑡1subscript𝑐𝑘subscript𝑏𝑘𝑡1D_{k}(t)=[D_{k}(t-1)+c_{k}-b_{k}(t-1)]^{+}, (27)

where [x]+=max⁡{x,0}superscriptdelimited-[]𝑥𝑥0[x]^{+}=\max\{x,0\} and Dk​(t)subscript𝐷𝑘𝑡D_{k}(t) indicates the queue length at the beginning of round t𝑡t. We define 𝐃​(t)=[D1​(t),D2​(t),…,DK​(t)]𝐃𝑡subscript𝐷1𝑡subscript𝐷2𝑡…subscript𝐷𝐾𝑡{\bf D}(t)=[D_{1}(t),D_{2}(t),\ldots,D_{K}(t)] and initialize 𝐃​(1)=𝟎𝐃10{\bf D}(1)=\mathbf{0}. The queue length decreases by 1 if arm k𝑘k is selected in round t−1𝑡1t-1, i.e., bk​(t−1)=1subscript𝑏𝑘𝑡11b_{k}(t-1)=1, and increases by cksubscript𝑐𝑘c_{k} in each round. Then, we give the criterion of choosing a super arm 𝒮​(t)𝒮𝑡{\mathcal{S}}(t) in each round t𝑡t which maximizes the compound value of y^k​(t)subscript^𝑦𝑘𝑡\hat{y}_{k}(t) and Dk​(t)subscript𝐷𝑘𝑡D_{k}(t), i.e.,

𝒮​(t)∈arg​max𝒮∈𝒬​(𝒜​(t)),|𝒮|=min⁡{N,|𝒜​(t)|}​∑k∈𝒮(1−β)​y^k​(t)+β​Dk​(t),𝒮𝑡subscriptargmax𝒮𝒬𝒜𝑡𝒮𝑁𝒜𝑡subscript𝑘𝒮1𝛽subscript^𝑦𝑘𝑡𝛽subscript𝐷𝑘𝑡{\mathcal{S}}(t)\in\operatornamewithlimits{arg\,max}_{\begin{subarray}{c}{\mathcal{S}}\in{\mathcal{Q}}({\mathcal{A}}(t)),\\ |{\mathcal{S}}|=\min\{N,|{\mathcal{A}}(t)|\}\end{subarray}}\sum_{k\in{\mathcal{S}}}(1-\beta)\hat{y}_{k}(t)+\beta D_{k}(t), (28)

where the weighting factor β∈[0,1]𝛽01\beta\in[0,1] is a non-negative constant. Similar to (18), the compound rewards of different clients are independent on each other, we can select the best individual arms iteratively.

IV-C Upper Bound on Regret

In this subsection, we first validate that the proposed CS-UCB-Q algorithm is feasibility-optimal. Then we provide an upper bound on the expected regret of the proposed CS-UCB-Q algorithm.

Theorem 3.

The proposed CS-UCB-Q algorithm presented in Algorithm 2 is feasibility-optimal. In other words, the fairness constraint in (6) is satisfied, for any 𝐜𝐜{\bf c} strictly in the maximal feasibility region 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}}.

Proof:

See Appendix C for reference. ∎

According to Theorem 3, the long-term fairness constraint can be satisfied under the proposed CS-UCB-Q algorithm presented in Algorithm 2 as long as the requirement is feasible, i.e., 𝐜𝐜{\bf c} is strictly in the maximal feasibility region 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}}.

Theorem 4.

The expected regret achieved by the proposed CS-UCB-Q algorithm presented in Algorithm 2 is upper bounded by

Σπ2≤β​Ω​T2+(1−β)​[(π23+1)​K+4​2​K​N​T​ln⁡T],superscriptΣsubscript𝜋2𝛽Ω𝑇21𝛽delimited-[]superscript𝜋231𝐾42𝐾𝑁𝑇𝑇\Sigma^{\pi_{2}}\leq\beta\frac{\Omega T}{2}+(1-\beta)\Big{[}(\frac{\pi^{2}}{3}+1)K+4\sqrt{2KNT\ln T}\Big{]}, (29)

where Ω=∑k∈𝒦max⁡{ck2,(1−ck)2}Ωsubscript𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑘2superscript1subscript𝑐𝑘2\Omega=\sum_{k\in{\mathcal{K}}}\max\{c_{k}^{2},(1-c_{k})^{2}\}. Typically when 0<β≤1T0𝛽1𝑇0<\beta\leq\frac{1}{\sqrt{T}} and T𝑇T is large enough, we have

Σπ2≤Ω​T2+(π23+1)​K+4​2​K​N​T​ln⁡T.superscriptΣsubscript𝜋2Ω𝑇2superscript𝜋231𝐾42𝐾𝑁𝑇𝑇\Sigma^{\pi_{2}}\leq\frac{\Omega\sqrt{T}}{2}+(\frac{\pi^{2}}{3}+1)K+4\sqrt{2KNT\ln T}. (30)
Proof:

The sketch of the proof is provided in Appendix D and refer to [39] for more details. ∎

Note that the regret bound in (29) has two terms where β𝛽\beta is attributed to achieve a balance between them. Specifically, when β𝛽\beta is large, i.e., a higher priority to satisfying the fairness constraint, the regret bound mainly depends on the first term and approximately is of the order 𝒪​(T)𝒪𝑇\mathcal{O}{(T)}. However, a small β𝛽\beta (e.g., β≤1T,T→+∞formulae-sequence𝛽1𝑇→𝑇\beta\leq\frac{1}{\sqrt{T}},T\rightarrow+\infty) suggests that the regret bound mainly depends on the second term and approximately is of the order 𝒪​(T​ln⁡T)𝒪𝑇𝑇\mathcal{O}{(\sqrt{T\ln T})}. In this case, the performance gap between the optimal solution and the solution found by the proposed CS-UCB-Q becomes smaller in the sub-linear way over communication rounds.

IV-D Convergence Analysis

Different from the ideal scenario, the datasets of the clients in the non-ideal scenario are heterogeneous. Here, we adopt a heuristic way to set the weights as ϖk​(t)=sk∑k′∈𝒦sk′subscriptitalic-ϖ𝑘𝑡subscript𝑠𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑘′𝒦subscript𝑠superscript𝑘′\varpi_{k}(t)=\frac{s_{k}}{\sum_{k^{\prime}\in{\mathcal{K}}}s_{k^{\prime}}} [1]. To prove the convergence, we need another assumption as follows:

Assumption 5.

(The first and second moment conditions [40]) The global loss function G​(𝐱)𝐺𝐱G({\bf x}) and the aggregation operation 𝐯​(t)𝐯𝑡{\bf v}(t) satisfy the following:

(a)

The global loss function G​(𝐱)𝐺𝐱G({\bf x}) is bounded by a scalar Ginf=G​(𝐱∗)superscript𝐺infimum𝐺superscript𝐱∗G^{\inf}=G({\bf x}^{\ast}).

(b)

Given two scalars δ1>δ2>0subscript𝛿1subscript𝛿20\delta_{1}>\delta_{2}>0, two constraints ‖𝔼​[𝐯​(t)]‖2≤δ1​‖∇G​(𝐱​(t))‖2subscriptnorm𝔼delimited-[]𝐯𝑡2subscript𝛿1subscriptnorm∇𝐺𝐱𝑡2||{\mathbb{E}}[{\bf v}(t)]||_{2}\leq\delta_{1}||\nabla G({\bf x}(t))||_{2} and ∇G†​(𝐱​(t))​𝔼​[𝐯​(t)]≥δ2​‖G​(𝐱​(t))‖22∇superscript𝐺†𝐱𝑡𝔼delimited-[]𝐯𝑡subscript𝛿2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝐺𝐱𝑡22\nabla G^{\dagger}({\bf x}(t)){\mathbb{E}}[{\bf v}(t)]\geq\delta_{2}||G({\bf x}(t))||_{2}^{2} always hold.

(c)

There exists δ3subscript𝛿3\delta_{3} such that 𝔼​‖𝐯​(t)‖22−‖𝔼​[𝐯​(t)]‖22≤δ3+‖∇G​(𝐱​(t))‖22𝔼superscriptsubscriptnorm𝐯𝑡22superscriptsubscriptnorm𝔼delimited-[]𝐯𝑡22subscript𝛿3superscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝐺𝐱𝑡22{\mathbb{E}}||{\bf v}(t)||_{2}^{2}-||{\mathbb{E}}[{\bf v}(t)]||_{2}^{2}\leq\delta_{3}+||\nabla G({\bf x}(t))||_{2}^{2}.

Theorem 5.

Under Assumptions 2, 3, and 5 and taking a fixed learning rate satisfying γ≤δ2L​(1+δ12)𝛾subscript𝛿2𝐿1superscriptsubscript𝛿12\gamma\leq\frac{\delta_{2}}{L(1+\delta_{1}^{2})} with L≥Φ𝐿ΦL\geq\Phi, we have

𝔼[G(𝐱(T))−G(𝐱∗)]≤γ​δ3​L2​Φ​δ2+(1−γδ2Φ)T−1𝔼[G(𝐱(1))]−G(𝐱∗)−γ​δ3​L2​Φ​δ2].\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}[G({\bf x}(T))-G({\bf x}^{\ast})]\leq\frac{\gamma\delta_{3}L}{2\Phi\delta_{2}}+(1-\gamma\delta_{2}\Phi)^{T-1}{\mathbb{E}}\bigg{[}G({\bf x}(1))]-G({\bf x}^{\ast})-\frac{\gamma\delta_{3}L}{2\Phi\delta_{2}}\bigg{]}. (31)
Proof:

See Appendix E for reference. ∎

According to Theorem 5, a smaller δ3subscript𝛿3\delta_{3} value leads to a better convergence performance. To decrease δ3subscript𝛿3\delta_{3} value, we can increase the number |𝒮​(t)|𝒮𝑡|{\mathcal{S}}(t)| of the participating clients in each round if possible. But their relationship is not so tight and thus the convergence rate has a weak dependence on |𝒮​(t)|𝒮𝑡|{\mathcal{S}}(t)|. Besides, we can involve the clients with important local datasets in more communication rounds to reduce δ3subscript𝛿3\delta_{3} value, which is realized by using the fairness constraint.

V Numerical Results

In this section, we conduct experiments to evaluate the performance of the proposed CS-UCB and CS-UCB-Q algorithms. As mentioned in Section II, the time cost τk​(t)subscript𝜏𝑘𝑡\tau_{k}(t) of each client k𝑘k in round t𝑡t is directly observed by the AP in practice. In our simulations, in order to obtain the value of τk​(t)subscript𝜏𝑘𝑡\tau_{k}(t), we first give the expressions to compute the three main components τkD​(t)subscriptsuperscript𝜏D𝑘𝑡\tau^{\textrm{D}}_{k}(t), τkLU​(t)subscriptsuperscript𝜏LU𝑘𝑡\tau^{\textrm{LU}}_{k}(t), and τkU​(t)subscriptsuperscript𝜏U𝑘𝑡\tau^{\textrm{U}}_{k}(t), respectively.

The average distribution time τkD​(t)subscriptsuperscript𝜏D𝑘𝑡\tau^{\textrm{D}}_{k}(t) of client k𝑘k in round t𝑡t is computed as

τkD​(t)=m0B​RkD​(t),subscriptsuperscript𝜏D𝑘𝑡subscript𝑚0𝐵subscriptsuperscript𝑅D𝑘𝑡\tau^{\textrm{D}}_{k}(t)=\frac{m_{0}}{BR^{\textrm{D}}_{k}(t)}, (32)

where m0subscript𝑚0m_{0} (in bits) is the size of data for distribution including the global model parameters, B𝐵B (in Hz) is the bandwidth of one channel, and RkD​(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑅D𝑘𝑡R^{\textrm{D}}_{k}(t) (in bits/s/Hz) is the average distribution rate for client k𝑘k in round t𝑡t. It is worth noting that the coherence time of wireless channels is relatively short, thus the distribution process may experience multiple coherence time slots in a communication round. In other words, the wireless channel varies during the distribution process. Here, we use the average distribution rate in a communication round instead of the instantaneous one because we focus on accelerating the learning process from the long-term learning perspective. The average distribution rate RkD​(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑅D𝑘𝑡R^{\textrm{D}}_{k}(t) in round t𝑡t is expressed as

RkD​(t)=log2⁡[1+pkD​|hkD​(t)|2σ2],subscriptsuperscript𝑅D𝑘𝑡subscript21subscriptsuperscript𝑝D𝑘superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptℎD𝑘𝑡2superscript𝜎2R^{\textrm{D}}_{k}(t)=\log_{2}\Big{[}1+\frac{p^{\textrm{D}}_{k}|h^{\textrm{D}}_{k}(t)|^{2}}{\sigma^{2}}\Big{]}, (33)

where pkDsubscriptsuperscript𝑝D𝑘p^{\textrm{D}}_{k} is the transmit power of the AP for client k𝑘k, σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} is the variance of additive white Gaussian noise, and hkD​(t)subscriptsuperscriptℎD𝑘𝑡h^{\textrm{D}}_{k}(t) is the average downlink channel gain of client k𝑘k in round t𝑡t.

Similarly, the upload time of client k𝑘k in round t𝑡t is

τkU​(t)=mkB​RkU​(t),subscriptsuperscript𝜏U𝑘𝑡subscript𝑚𝑘𝐵subscriptsuperscript𝑅U𝑘𝑡\tau^{\textrm{U}}_{k}(t)=\frac{m_{k}}{BR^{\textrm{U}}_{k}(t)}, (34)

where mksubscript𝑚𝑘m_{k} is the data size of client k𝑘k for upload and RkU​(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑅U𝑘𝑡R^{\textrm{U}}_{k}(t) in bits/s/Hz denotes the average upload rate of client k𝑘k in round t𝑡t, which is given as

RkU​(t)=log2⁡[1+pkU​|hkU​(t)|2σ2],subscriptsuperscript𝑅U𝑘𝑡subscript21subscriptsuperscript𝑝U𝑘superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptℎU𝑘𝑡2superscript𝜎2R^{\textrm{U}}_{k}(t)=\log_{2}\Big{[}1+\frac{p^{\textrm{U}}_{k}|h^{\textrm{U}}_{k}(t)|^{2}}{\sigma^{2}}\Big{]}, (35)

where pkUsubscriptsuperscript𝑝U𝑘p^{\textrm{U}}_{k} is the transmit power of client k𝑘k and hkU​(t)subscriptsuperscriptℎU𝑘𝑡h^{\textrm{U}}_{k}(t) is the average uplink channel gain of client k𝑘k in round t𝑡t.

In addition, the local update time of client k𝑘k in round t𝑡t is calculated as

τkLU​(t)=ϱkϕk​(t).subscriptsuperscript𝜏LU𝑘𝑡subscriptitalic-ϱ𝑘subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘𝑡\tau^{\textrm{LU}}_{k}(t)=\frac{\varrho_{k}}{\phi_{k}(t)}. (36)

where ϱksubscriptitalic-ϱ𝑘\varrho_{k} is the number of sample points for the local updates in each round. For example, ϱk=sksubscriptitalic-ϱ𝑘subscript𝑠𝑘\varrho_{k}=s_{k} in the gradient descent method and ϱk=ϱ,∀k∈𝒦,formulae-sequencesubscriptitalic-ϱ𝑘italic-ϱfor-all𝑘𝒦\varrho_{k}=\varrho,\forall k\in{\mathcal{K}}, in the stochastic gradient descent (SGD) method with ϱitalic-ϱ\varrho being the mini-batch size. Finally, we can calculate τk​(t)subscript𝜏𝑘𝑡\tau_{k}(t) according to (4).

V-A Experiment Settings

The system setting is summarized as follows unless otherwise specified. We consider a network where a single-antenna AP is located in the centre of the network with a disc of 500m and the clients randomly distributed within the coverage of the AP. The channel gains of both the uplink and downlink links are composed of both small-scale fading and large-scale fading, where the small-scale fading is set as Rayleigh distribution with uniform variance and the large scale fading are generated using the path-loss model: PL[dB]=128.1+37.6​log10⁡(d)PL[dB]128.137.6subscript10𝑑\text{PL}\text{[dB]}=128.1+37.6\log_{10}(d) with d𝑑d representing the distance in km. The noise power σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} is -107 dBm and the bandwidth of each orthogonal channel is 15 KHz. Both the uplink and downlink transmit power is 23 dBm, i.e., pkU=pkD=23​dBm,∀k∈𝒦formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝑝U𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑝D𝑘23dBmfor-all𝑘𝒦p^{\text{U}}_{k}=p^{\text{D}}_{k}=23\ \text{dBm},\forall k\in{\mathcal{K}}. The computing capability ϕk​(t)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘𝑡\phi_{k}(t) of each client k𝑘k is uniformly distributed in [ϕkLB,ϕkUB]subscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϕLB𝑘subscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϕUB𝑘[\phi^{\text{LB}}_{k},\phi^{\text{UB}}_{k}], where ϕkLBsubscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϕLB𝑘\phi^{\text{LB}}_{k} and ϕkUBsubscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϕUB𝑘\phi^{\text{UB}}_{k} are the lower bound and upper bound, respectively. Here, we assume ϕkLB=(0.5​k+0.5)×20subscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϕLB𝑘0.5𝑘0.520\phi^{\text{LB}}_{k}=(0.5k+0.5)\times 20 and ϕkUB=(0.5​k+1.5)×20,∀k∈𝒦formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϕUB𝑘0.5𝑘1.520for-all𝑘𝒦\phi^{\text{UB}}_{k}=(0.5k+1.5)\times 20,\forall k\in{\mathcal{K}}. In addition, for simplicity, we assume m0=mk=5×103subscript𝑚0subscript𝑚𝑘5superscript103m_{0}=m_{k}=5\times 10^{3} bits and the maximal interval τmax=5subscript𝜏5\tau_{\max}=5 seconds.

We study image classification of handwritten digits 0-9 in the well-known MNIST dataset using multinomial logistic regression. The training and test sets consist of 60,000 and 10,000 samples, respectively. The SGD method is adopted, where the mini-batch size ϱitalic-ϱ\varrho is 2 and the learning rate is 0.001.

V-B Performance in Ideal Scenario

In the ideal scenario, it is assumed that there are K=20𝐾20K=20 clients and N=5𝑁5N=5 channels available in each communication round. The dataset is shuffled and then partitioned into the clients equally. Before giving the numerical results, we introduce two baseline algorithms for comparison [41]. The first one is a random scheduling algorithm where the AP uniformly selects N𝑁N clients at random in each communication round for model updates. The second one is the round robin algorithm in which the clients are divided into groups each with N𝑁N clients and the AP consecutively assigns each group to access to the radio channels and update their parameters per communication round. We define Θ=τmax​Σπ1Θsubscript𝜏superscriptΣsubscript𝜋1\Theta=\tau_{\max}\Sigma^{\pi_{1}} and θ=Θ/T𝜃Θ𝑇\theta=\Theta/T as the cumulative and average performance gaps, respectively, where π1subscript𝜋1\pi_{1} can be the proposed CS-UCB algorithm or the introduced baseline algorithms. Note that some clients selected in a certain round may not be able to send to its results to the AP for aggregation, e.g., due to the large propagation delay or processing delay. According to (4), we refer to client k𝑘k with τk=τmax=5subscript𝜏𝑘subscript𝜏5\tau_{k}=\tau_{\max}=5 seconds as a failed client and count the cumulative number of the failed clients.

As seen from Fig. 1, the proposed CS-UCB algorithm achieves better performance than the two baseline algorithms after 20 rounds and the performance gap increases as the number of communication rounds increases. This is because the proposed CS-UCB algorithm keeps learning the statistical information of each client in the execution process and leverage a tradeoff between the exploitation of learned knowledge and the exploration of more potential actions. It is also observed from Fig. 1, the proposed CS-UCB algorithm has less failed clients, which suggests that in a given time interval, more clients can get involved in the learning process for more communication rounds.

Before showing the convergence performance, in addition to the existing baseline algorithms, we introduce another baseline algorithm, named local accuracy based scheduling, where the clients with lower local test accuracy have higher priority to be chosen in each round. The test accuracy with respect to the number of communication rounds of different algorithms is shown in Fig. 3. We find that the convergence rate, in terms of the communication rounds, of the proposed CS-UCB algorithm in the ideal scenario is close to those of the baselines. This is because the local datasets of the clients are i.i.d. and the average number of the participating clients in each round is almost the same. Based on the results of Figs. 1(a) and 3, we can conclude that the proposed CS-UCB algorithm consumes less wall-clock time to finish the required communication rounds of a certain level of test accuracy.

In Fig. 3, we fix T=5000𝑇5000T=5000 and show the performance of different algorithms with respect to the number of available channels N𝑁N. It is observed that the performance of the proposed CS-UCB algorithm is always better than those of the random scheduling algorithm and the round robin algorithm. Besides, we observe that the cumulative performance gap increases as the number of available channels increases because more clients can get involved in the FL process and then the probability of choosing the high-latency clients is increased.

V-C Performance in Non-Ideal Scenario

Before showing the performance of the proposed CS-UCB-Q algorithm, a baseline algorithm based on the proposed CS-UCB algorithm is introduced for comparison, which takes the availability of clients into account but does not consider the fairness constraint. Thus, we refer to such a baseline algorithm as modified CS-UCB algorithm. The cumulative and average performance gains are given as Θ=τmax​Σπ2Θsubscript𝜏superscriptΣsubscript𝜋2\Theta=\tau_{\max}\Sigma^{\pi_{2}} and θ=Θ/T𝜃Θ𝑇\theta=\Theta/T, respectively, where π2subscript𝜋2\pi_{2} can be the proposed CS-UCB-Q algorithm or the modified CS-UCB algorithm. We consider a system with K=3𝐾3K=3 and N=2𝑁2N=2, where the fairness constraint vector is set as 𝐜=(c1,c2,c3)=(0.6,0.5,0.4)𝐜subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2subscript𝑐30.60.50.4{\bf c}=(c_{1},c_{2},c_{3})=(0.6,0.5,0.4) and the sample vector is 𝐬=(s1,s2,s3)=(1500,1000,500)𝐬subscript𝑠1subscript𝑠2subscript𝑠315001000500\mathbf{s}=(s_{1},s_{2},s_{3})=(1500,1000,500). Besides, the availability of each client k𝑘k is a binary random variable with mean αksubscript𝛼𝑘\alpha_{k} which is i.i.d. over time. For simplicity, we set αk=0.9,∀k∈𝒦formulae-sequencesubscript𝛼𝑘0.9for-all𝑘𝒦\alpha_{k}=0.9,\forall k\in{\mathcal{K}}.

In Fig. 4, different β𝛽\beta values are considered and these β𝛽\beta values make the proposed CS-UCB-Q algorithm meet the fairness constraint. Different from the proposed CS-UCB-Q algorithm, the modified CS-UCB algorithm is unaware of the fairness constraint and thus can achieve the smallest performance gap, which is even negative, i.e., it achieves better performance than the optimal solution obtained by solving the linear program (23). Besides, we also find that a smaller β𝛽\beta value in the proposed CS-UCB-Q algorithm results in a smaller performance gap since the importance of the fairness constraint is reduced and more priority is given to the reward of each client. Such an observation at first glance seems to suggest that the proposed CS-UCB-Q algorithm with a smaller β𝛽\beta value is more attractive as it achieves a better performance while satisfying the fairness constraint. However, the speed of convergence to a point that meets the fairness constraint is not reflected in Fig. 4, which is also an important concern in practice.

Fig. 5 presents the selection fractions of different clients with respect to the number of communication rounds. We find that the curve with a smaller β𝛽\beta value has a slow speed of convergence to the point satisfying the fairness constraint. For example, the convergence rate of the proposed CS-UCB-Q algorithm with β=10−5𝛽superscript105\beta=10^{-5} is the slowest and the fairness constraint of client 1 is violated in the whole learning process. Thus, there is a tradeoff between the performance and the convergence rate. Besides, we can infer from Fig. 5 that the reward of client 1 is the lowest and that of client 3 is the highest. In other words, the time consumed by the client 1 to finish its local training and transmission is the longest and that of client 3 is the shortest. This is because, without the limitation of fairness, the modified CS-UCB algorithm tends to choose the fast clients to participate in the FL process.

To simulate a heterogeneous setting in the non-ideal scenario, we distribute the training samples among K=10𝐾10K=10 clients such that two clients have samples of 5 digits and the other clients have samples of only 1 digit. We assume that the fairness factor is proportional to the size of local dataset, i.e., ck=N2​sk∑k∈𝒦sksubscript𝑐𝑘𝑁2subscript𝑠𝑘subscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝑠𝑘c_{k}=\frac{N}{2}\frac{s_{k}}{\sum_{k\in{\mathcal{K}}}s_{k}} with N=4𝑁4N=4. The test accuracy with respect to the number of communication rounds of the proposed CS-UCB-Q algorithm, as well as the baseline algorithms, is presented in Fig. 7. It is shown that the achieved test accuracy of the proposed CS-UCB-Q algorithm is better than that of the three baseline algorithms. This is because the proposed CS-UCB-Q algorithm makes the clients with the important datasets participate in more rounds. According to the results of Figs. 4(a) and 7, we find that the proposed CS-UCB-Q algorithm can reduce the training latency without degrading the learning performance. In other words, given the number of communication rounds required to achieve a certain level of test accuracy, the proposed CS-UCB-Q algorithm can finish the FL training process with less wall-clock time.

To show the performance with respect to the number of available channels N𝑁N, we assume that the fairness constraint is proportional to the size of the local dataset of each client, i.e., ck=ρ​sk∑k∈𝒦sksubscript𝑐𝑘𝜌subscript𝑠𝑘subscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝑠𝑘c_{k}=\rho\frac{s_{k}}{\sum_{k\in{\mathcal{K}}}s_{k}}, where ρ𝜌\rho is a scaling factor. As shown in Fig. 7, the larger ρ𝜌\rho value leads to a larger delay. This is because the larger ρ𝜌\rho value suggests that more communication rounds are forced to meet the requirement for the fairness constraint and thus the slow clients can participate in more communication rounds, leading to more time consumption.

VI Conclusions

Aiming to minimize the time consumption of FL training, this work considered the CS problem in both the ideal scenario and non-ideal scenarios. For the ideal scenario, we proposed the CS-UCB algorithm and also derived an upper bound of its performance regret. The upper bound suggests that the performance regret of the proposed CS-UCB algorithm grows in a logarithmic way over communication rounds. However, the local datasets of clients are non-i.i.d. and unbalanced and the availability of clients is dynamic in the non-ideal scenario. Thus, we introduced the fairness constraint to ensure each client could participate in a certain proportion of the communication rounds during the training process. We further proposed the CS-UCB-Q algorithm based on UCB policy and virtual queue technique and provided an upper bound which shows that the performance regret of the proposed CS-UCB-Q algorithm has a sub-linear growth over communication rounds when β≤1T𝛽1𝑇\beta\leq\frac{1}{\sqrt{T}} and T𝑇T is large enough. Simulation results validate the efficiency of the proposed CS-UCB and CS-UCB-Q algorithms and also reveal a tradeoff between the performance regret and the speed of convergence to a point where the fairness constraint is satisfied.

Appendix B Proof of Theorem 2

According to Assumption 2 and taking γ≤1L𝛾1𝐿\gamma\leq\frac{1}{L}, we have

G​(𝐱​(t+1))−G​(𝐱​(t))𝐺𝐱𝑡1𝐺𝐱𝑡\displaystyle G({\bf x}(t+1))-G({\bf x}(t)) ≤−γ​∇G†​(𝐱​(t))​𝐯​(t)+γ2​‖𝐯​(t)‖22absent𝛾∇superscript𝐺†𝐱𝑡𝐯𝑡𝛾2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝐯𝑡22\displaystyle\leq-\gamma\nabla G^{{\dagger}}({\bf x}(t)){\bf v}(t)+\frac{\gamma}{2}||{\bf v}(t)||_{2}^{2}
=−γ2​‖∇G​(𝐱​(t))‖22+γ2​‖∇G​(𝐱​(t))−𝐯​(t)‖22.absent𝛾2superscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝐺𝐱𝑡22𝛾2superscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝐺𝐱𝑡𝐯𝑡22\displaystyle=-\frac{\gamma}{2}||\nabla G({\bf x}(t))||_{2}^{2}+\frac{\gamma}{2}||\nabla G({\bf x}(t))-{\bf v}(t)||_{2}^{2}. (45)

which suggests that

2​Φ​[G​(𝐱​(t))−G​(𝐱∗)]≤‖∇G​(𝐱​(t))‖22.2Φdelimited-[]𝐺𝐱𝑡𝐺superscript𝐱∗superscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝐺𝐱𝑡222\Phi[G({\bf x}(t))-G({\bf x}^{\ast})]\leq||\nabla G({\bf x}(t))||_{2}^{2}. (48)

which is a contraction inequality because of 0<γ​Φ≤10𝛾Φ10<\gamma\Phi\leq 1. Finally, the result in Theorem 2 can be obtained by applying (51) repeatedly.

Appendix C Proof of Theorem 3

To validate Theorem 3, we need to prove that all the virtual queues defined in (27) is mean rate stable [38, Definition 2.2], i.e.,

Appendix D Proof of Theorem 4

Given the optimal 𝒜𝒜{\mathcal{A}}-policy π2∗superscriptsubscript𝜋2∗\pi_{2}^{\ast}, we denote by 𝒮∗​(t)superscript𝒮∗𝑡{\mathcal{S}}^{\ast}(t) the super arm chosen in round t𝑡t by policy π2∗superscriptsubscript𝜋2∗\pi_{2}^{\ast} and bk∗​(t)superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘∗𝑡b_{k}^{\ast}(t)’s are the indicator variables that correspond to 𝒮∗​(t)superscript𝒮∗𝑡{\mathcal{S}}^{\ast}(t). Furthermore, we define Υ1​(t)=∑k∈𝒦(bk∗​(t)−bk​(t))​μksubscriptΥ1𝑡subscript𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘∗𝑡subscript𝑏𝑘𝑡subscript𝜇𝑘\Upsilon_{1}(t)=\sum_{k\in{\mathcal{K}}}\big{(}b_{k}^{\ast}(t)-b_{k}(t)\big{)}\mu_{k} and Υ2​(t)=∑k∈𝒦[β​Dk​(t)+(1−β)​μk]​(bk∗​(t)−bk​(t))subscriptΥ2𝑡subscript𝑘𝒦delimited-[]𝛽subscript𝐷𝑘𝑡1𝛽subscript𝜇𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑏∗𝑘𝑡subscript𝑏𝑘𝑡\Upsilon_{2}(t)=\sum_{k\in{\mathcal{K}}}[\beta D_{k}(t)+(1-\beta)\mu_{k}]\big{(}b^{\ast}_{k}(t)-b_{k}(t)\big{)}. The following lemma gives a related inequality between Υ1​(t)subscriptΥ1𝑡\Upsilon_{1}(t) and Υ2​(t)subscriptΥ2𝑡\Upsilon_{2}(t).

Lemma 2.

The sum of the time sequence 𝔼​[Υ1​(t)],t=1,2,…,Tformulae-sequence𝔼delimited-[]subscriptΥ1𝑡𝑡12…𝑇{\mathbb{E}}[\Upsilon_{1}(t)],t=1,2,\ldots,T, is bounded by

∑t=1T𝔼​[Υ1​(t)]≤β​Ω​T2+∑t=1T𝔼​[Υ2​(t)].subscriptsuperscript𝑇𝑡1𝔼delimited-[]subscriptΥ1𝑡𝛽Ω𝑇2subscriptsuperscript𝑇𝑡1𝔼delimited-[]subscriptΥ2𝑡\begin{split}\sum^{T}_{t=1}{\mathbb{E}}[\Upsilon_{1}(t)]&\leq\frac{\beta\Omega T}{2}+\sum^{T}_{t=1}{\mathbb{E}}\left[\Upsilon_{2}(t)\right].\end{split} (60)
Proof:

To validate Lemma 2, we first introduce a variable ξ(t)=β[L(𝐃(t+1))−L(𝐃(t)]+(1−β)Υ1(t)\xi(t)=\beta[L({\bf D}(t+1))-L({\bf D}(t)]+(1-\beta)\Upsilon_{1}(t) which is referred to as the drift-plus-regret. The upper bound of 𝔼​[ξ​(t)]𝔼delimited-[]𝜉𝑡{\mathbb{E}}[\xi(t)] is given as

𝔼​[ξ​(t)]≤β​𝔼​[Ω2+∑k∈𝒦(ck−bk​(t))​Dk​(t)]+(1−β)​𝔼​[∑k∈𝒦bk∗​(t)​μk−∑k∈𝒦bk​(t)​μk]=β​Ω2+𝔼​[Υ2​(t)]+β​∑k∈𝒦𝔼​[Dk​(t)​(ck−bk∗​(t))]≤β​Ω2+𝔼​[Υ2​(t)],𝔼delimited-[]𝜉𝑡𝛽𝔼delimited-[]Ω2subscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝑐𝑘subscript𝑏𝑘𝑡subscript𝐷𝑘𝑡1𝛽𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘∗𝑡subscript𝜇𝑘subscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝑏𝑘𝑡subscript𝜇𝑘𝛽Ω2𝔼delimited-[]subscriptΥ2𝑡𝛽subscript𝑘𝒦𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐷𝑘𝑡subscript𝑐𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑏∗𝑘𝑡𝛽Ω2𝔼delimited-[]subscriptΥ2𝑡\begin{split}{\mathbb{E}}[\xi(t)]&\leq\beta{\mathbb{E}}\Big{[}\frac{\Omega}{2}+\sum_{k\in{\mathcal{K}}}(c_{k}-b_{k}(t))D_{k}(t)\Big{]}+(1-\beta){\mathbb{E}}\Big{[}\sum_{k\in{\mathcal{K}}}b_{k}^{\ast}(t)\mu_{k}-\sum_{k\in{\mathcal{K}}}b_{k}(t)\mu_{k}\Big{]}\\ &=\frac{\beta\Omega}{2}+{\mathbb{E}}[\Upsilon_{2}(t)]+\beta\sum_{k\in{\mathcal{K}}}{\mathbb{E}}[D_{k}(t)(c_{k}-b^{\ast}_{k}(t))]\leq\frac{\beta\Omega}{2}+{\mathbb{E}}[\Upsilon_{2}(t)],\end{split} (61)

where the last inequality holds because of (6). By summing 𝔼​[ξ​(t)]𝔼delimited-[]𝜉𝑡{\mathbb{E}}[\xi(t)] over t=1,2​…,T𝑡12…𝑇t=1,2\ldots,T, we obtain

Since L​(𝐃​(1))=0𝐿𝐃10L({\bf D}(1))=0 and L​(𝐃​(T+1))≥0𝐿𝐃𝑇10L({\bf D}(T+1))\geq 0, we obtain the inequality (60) directly. The proof of Lemma 2 is completed. ∎

the expected regret is bounded by

Appendix E Proof of Theorem 5

According to Assumption 2 and taking expectation on 𝐯​(t)𝐯𝑡{\bf v}(t), we have

𝔼​[G​(𝐱​(t+1))]−G​(𝐱​(t))≤−γ​∇G†​(𝐱​(t))​𝔼​[𝐯​(t)]+L​γ22​𝔼​‖𝐯​(t)‖22,𝔼delimited-[]𝐺𝐱𝑡1𝐺𝐱𝑡𝛾∇superscript𝐺†𝐱𝑡𝔼delimited-[]𝐯𝑡𝐿superscript𝛾22𝔼superscriptsubscriptnorm𝐯𝑡22{\mathbb{E}}[G({\bf x}(t+1))]-G({\bf x}(t))\leq-\gamma\nabla G^{{\dagger}}({\bf x}(t)){\mathbb{E}}[{\bf v}(t)]+\frac{L\gamma^{2}}{2}{\mathbb{E}}||{\bf v}(t)||_{2}^{2}, (69)

where 𝔼​‖𝐯​(t)‖22𝔼superscriptsubscriptnorm𝐯𝑡22{\mathbb{E}}||{\bf v}(t)||_{2}^{2} is bounded by, based on Assumptions 5(b) and 5(c),

𝔼​‖𝐯​(t)‖22𝔼superscriptsubscriptnorm𝐯𝑡22\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}||{\bf v}(t)||_{2}^{2} ≤‖𝔼​[𝐯​(t)]‖22+δ3+‖∇G​(𝐱​(t))‖22≤δ3+(1+δ12)​‖∇G​(𝐱​(t))‖22.absentsuperscriptsubscriptnorm𝔼delimited-[]𝐯𝑡22subscript𝛿3superscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝐺𝐱𝑡22subscript𝛿31subscriptsuperscript𝛿21superscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝐺𝐱𝑡22\displaystyle\leq||{\mathbb{E}}[{\bf v}(t)]||_{2}^{2}+\delta_{3}+||\nabla G({\bf x}(t))||_{2}^{2}\leq\delta_{3}+(1+\delta^{2}_{1})||\nabla G({\bf x}(t))||_{2}^{2}. (70)

Thus,

𝔼​[G​(𝐱​(t+1))]−G​(𝐱​(t))𝔼delimited-[]𝐺𝐱𝑡1𝐺𝐱𝑡\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}[G({\bf x}(t+1))]-G({\bf x}(t)) ≤−γ​[δ2−L​γ2​(1+δ12)]​‖∇G​(𝐱​(t))‖22+L​γ2​δ32absent𝛾delimited-[]subscript𝛿2𝐿𝛾21subscriptsuperscript𝛿21superscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝐺𝐱𝑡22𝐿superscript𝛾2subscript𝛿32\displaystyle\leq-\gamma[\delta_{2}-\frac{L\gamma}{2}(1+\delta^{2}_{1})]||\nabla G({\bf x}(t))||_{2}^{2}+\frac{L\gamma^{2}\delta_{3}}{2}
≤−γ​δ22​‖∇G​(𝐱​(t))‖22+L​γ2​δ32,absent𝛾subscript𝛿22superscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝐺𝐱𝑡22𝐿superscript𝛾2subscript𝛿32\displaystyle\leq-\frac{\gamma\delta_{2}}{2}||\nabla G({\bf x}(t))||_{2}^{2}+\frac{L\gamma^{2}\delta_{3}}{2}, (71)

where the second inequality holds because of γ≤δ2L​(1+δ12)𝛾subscript𝛿2𝐿1superscriptsubscript𝛿12\gamma\leq\frac{\delta_{2}}{L(1+\delta_{1}^{2})}. Finally, we take similar actions in (47)-(50) and the proof is completed.
